node.title: Medicare Proposes to Cover Aduhelm Only for Patients in Clinical Trials
node.alt: Aduhelm was approved by the F.D.A. in June in a decision that has been criticized by many doctors and Alzheimerâ€™s experts who say the treatment showed significant safety risks and unclear benefit to patients during its clinical trials.
node.description: Officials of the federal health insurance program are expected to finalize their decision in the spring, after a 30-day comment period.
node.content: ["Medicare officials have decided that the federal health insurance program should only cover the controversial new Alzheimer\u2019s drug Aduhelm for patients who are participating in approved clinical trials. The preliminary decision, reached after lengthy deliberations, was released on Tuesday by the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, or C.M.S. If it is finalized later this year, it would significantly limit the number of patients who could use the expensive drug.", "The decision said that coverage should be provided for patients in \u201cC.M.S. approved randomized controlled trials\u201d and trials supported by the National Institutes of Health. The decision said \u201call trials must be conducted in a hospital-based outpatient setting.\u201d", "The agency added that Aduhelm of other similar drugs for Alzheimer\u2019s that are provided outside of these trials \u201care nationally non-covered.\u201d", "\u201cAlzheimer\u2019s disease is a devastating illness that has touched the lives of millions of American families. Throughout this National Coverage Determination process, CMS has been and remains committed to providing the American public with a clear, trusted, evidence-based decision that is made only after a thorough analysis of public feedback on the benefits and risks of coverage for Medicare patients,\u201d said the C.M.S. administrator, Chiquita Brooks-LaSure. \u201cC.M.S. has proposed an evidence-based coverage policy after experts reviewed all relevant publicly available evidence and feedback received from stakeholders.\u201d", "Whether Medicare ends up covering Aduhelm is considered pivotal to the future of the drug, which is made by Biogen and priced at $28,200 a year per patient. Roughly 80 percent of the 1.5 million Americans who have the type of condition the F.D.A. approved the drug to treat \u2014 mild Alzheimer\u2019s-related cognitive decline \u2014 are old enough to receive coverage under Medicare.", "For the next 30 days, C.M.S. will have a public comment period on the preliminary decision, and the agency is expected to announce its final decision about covering the drug by mid-April.", "The fact that Medicare is conducting an extensive review of Aduhelm is itself unusual. The program almost always pays for F.D.A.-approved drugs, at least for the medical conditions designated on their label, health policy experts said.", "Biogen initially priced the drug at $56,000 a year, but slashed the price in half last month after months of weak sales. Before Biogen\u2019s price cut, Medicare\u2019s actuarial division, acting without knowing what the coverage decision would be, imposed one of the biggest-ever increases in Medicare Part B premiums for 2022, partly driven by the possibility of Aduhelm coverage.", "After Biogen\u2019s price cut, advocacy groups for Alzheimer\u2019s patients urged C.M.S. to lower the premium increase. On Monday, the secretary for health and human services, Xavier Becerra, said that he was instructing C.M.S. to re-examine the premium hike \u201cgiven the dramatic price change of the Alzheimer\u2019s drug, Aduhelm.\u201d", "Aduhelm was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in June in a decision vigorously criticized by many doctors and Alzheimer\u2019s experts because clinical trial results showed it had significant safety risks and unclear benefit to patients.", "Congress is investigating whether the F.D.A. worked too closely with Biogen and why Aduhelm was approved despite strong objections from some senior F.D.A. officials and the agency\u2019s independent advisory committee.", "So far, only a small number of patients \u2014 a fraction of the number Biogen and industry analysts had initially expected \u2014 have used Aduhelm, a monoclonal antibody administered as a monthly infusion. Many large American health care systems have declined to offer the drug, citing questions about its benefits and risks.", " Medicare officials are supposed to determine coverage based on whether a drug is a \u201creasonable and necessary\u201d treatment, a phrase that usually \u201cmeans adequate evidence of improved health outcomes,\u201d said Dr. Sean Tunis, a former official with C.M.S. who is now a senior fellow at the Center for the Evaluation of Value and Risk in Health at Tufts Medical Center.", "Medicare\u2019s decision on Aduhelm will also establish standards for evaluating several similar Alzheimer\u2019s drugs in the pipeline.", "The F.D.A. itself acknowledged in its approval of Aduhelm that there was insufficient evidence it would help patients. Instead, it greenlighted the medication \u2014 the first new treatment for Alzheimer\u2019s in 18 years \u2014 under a program called \u201caccelerated approval,\u201d which allows authorization of unproven drugs for serious diseases with few treatment options if the drug affects a biological mechanism in a way considered \u201creasonably likely to predict clinical benefit.\u201d", "The F.D.A. said it based accelerated approval on Aduhelm\u2019s reduction of a protein, called amyloid, that clumps into plaques in the brains of people with Alzheimer\u2019s. But many Alzheimer\u2019s specialists say that extensive research has shown little evidence that reducing amyloid slows cognitive decline. The F.D.A. also required Biogen to conduct another clinical trial to determine if the drug provided any evidence of benefit. In the years it will take for that trial to be completed, Aduhelm will be available to patients."]
